Nothing special here.  Went for Sunday brunch.  The buffet looked very delicious, I had an a la cart omelet that was very good, however nothing to write home about.  Service was rather mediocre as well.  Nothing horrible about this place, but nothing special either.  I will not go back, due to the abundance of better places in the area.

Happy Thanksgiving. I have a lot to be thankful for. This place and the experience I had was definitely not one of them. To save you some time, my honest opinion is that I woulde NOT pick Nan & Byron's for anything again.

My wife and I decided to see my family in Dallas during Christmas break so we stayed in Charlotte and I chose Nan & Byron's for lunch after the Novant Health Thanksgiving parade because Capital Grille was all booked and I go to 5Church too often. The fact that the same management runs 5Church made me feel confident about my decision.

They weren't ready when we walked in. We walk in, tell the guy who greeted us that we had a reservation and he goes, "you don't have a reservation?" in the way that sounded like 'why are you here so early.' I did have a reservation by the way. He just didn't hear me right the first time.

He shows us the table and while we walk towards it, there's the entire restaurant employees sitting in a circle chatting although their business hours clearly started. By this time, I'm pretty much thinking this is going to be a disaster so let's try my best to have fun.

So, we wait for the apps, and we got happy because the biscuits and the salads were good. The turkey and the pork were not good, on the other hand. I tried to be a good sport though. And that was my Thanksgiving lunch at Nan & Byron's, where I didn't find a reason to go back to.

Went for business dinner and was extremely disappointed. Ordered Farmhouse Lemonade, their signature drink, and while tasty it was a very light pour. I'm a complete lightweight and didn't notice anything after 2 rounds.

Service was polite but extremely slow. No complimentary popcorn. Few patrons, waited over an hour for food while surrounding tables were served. Food was cold. We all tried each other's dishes. The mushroom soup was viscous and dirty tasting. I've never had a mushroom soup that I couldn't eat. It was like drinking gravy. Waitress didnt ask why it was untouched. The meatloaf was bland and looked old. Vegetables were frozen peas and carrots out of the bag, seriously...they couldn't cut up their own carrots. Mashed potatoes were gummy. My boss didn't finish her scallops but didn't say anything. Ordered a side of grits, there was no salt in them and they were gummy instead of creamy.

The staff seemed fine. I think the problem is in the kitchen. They don't know how to manage the orders and the food isn't fresh or seasoned appropriately. I hope they fix this, but I'll never know. There are so many better places in Charlotte to eat.

Oh, and grammatical errors on printed menu....

We dined here on Thursday but I've been putting off writing this review because I could not decide how I wanted to rate this place.. but I finally came to a decision- 3.5 stars. The food was tasty, for the most part, & our server was friendly, but there was some confusion about what sides we ordered and some of the food we received wasn't even warm by the time it got to our table. Fortunately, management stepped up & took care of things.. well, mostly.

As soon as we were seated, we were given a bowl of the addictive, seasoned popcorn. I'm a mindless snacker & we ended up going through 2 bowls throughout our meal.. plus we took a fresh batch home :) I ordered Dancing Cranberries, which consisted of prosecco, white cranberry juice, and dried cranberries. It was very good & what an apropos name for this drink! The little cranberries were bouncing around due to the carbonation of the prosecco.. pretty amusing.. or maybe I'm just easily amused?

We got the peppadew popper app & it was quite good as well, though nothing amazing. I think I would have preferred a different type of pepper, with a little more spice & less sweetness, but that's just me. I mean, it was still tasty.. you really can't go wrong with fried, cheese-stuffed peppers!

For my entree, I went with the mushroom & for my 2 sides I went potato on potato & got the mojito fries & mashed potatoes. BF ordered the meatloaf with slaw & corn as his sides. Our entrees arrived in a timely manner, but this is also where the confusion started. My mushroom had its quinoa stuffing but there was also some corn under it & I got my mojito fries. BF got his meatloaf, also with corn under it.. & sweet potato fries? We were each given a side we didn't order but our server said we could still keep them & brought out our other sides shortly after. Problem #1 solved.. or so I thought.

The second problem was that our food wasn't even warm. In fact, my mashed potatoes were straight up COLD. Not acceptable. My mushroom was room temperature & BF's meatloaf was barely warm, but he was still ok with it. I let our server know that my entree wasn't even warm, let alone hot, & told her it wasn't that big of a deal & if she could just stick it in the microwave to heat it up, I'd be fine, but she was extremely gracious about it & said they could cook a brand new one for me. I appreciated that but I don't like sending food back because it makes me feel high maintenance. I let her take the mushroom & kept quiet about my mashed potatoes & just took them home (they turned out to be very good after I heated them up).

My food was actually better than I expected, when it finally arrived, hot. I did notice that mushroom #2 was significantly smaller than mushroom #1 but whatever, at least I finally had an edible entree. The only thing I didn't really enjoy was the quinoa stuffing, but the portobello itself was deliciously marinated & nicely grilled. The mojito fries were also tasty. Normally, I'm pretty apprehensive about mint being in savory foods (the same way I feel about fruit inside salads.. *shudder*) but the flavors worked very well & I loved the little bit of tartness. I think BF liked the meatloaf & he said the sriracha ketchup was subtly spicy (which to him is a good thing).

After we were done eating, our bill arrived & our server let us know they comped the mushroom for all of the trouble, which was pleasantly unexpected. However, we also noticed that we were charged for the slaw, when we shouldn't have been. I know, it's only $4, but the slaw was supposed to come with my BF's meal.. whatever. I just let it go because they DID take the mushroom off the bill & I felt like I was being super high maintenance all night. Still, it was a bit of a wtf moment.

Despite all of the trouble, I can definitely see the potential in this place. They really do care about their customer's experience. We will be back & hopefully I will think this place is more than A-OK :)

I have been to Nan and Byron's several times now and love it more each time. The Nightshade Martini is hands down the best martini I've ever tasted. My favorite entree is the 8 oz. Prime Rib with the mac n cheese. The mac n cheese is a MUST TRY. Great service, great environment - definitely recommend this place.

Quite disappointed in our visit today on Memorial Day. After being seated and given our glasses of water we received zero attention from the staff. I should preface this by saying they were most likely understaffed and weren't expecting customers on a holiday. We noticed several tables had been sitting for a long time with no food or drinks on the table. Then we saw a family sit down and didn't get any service for over 15min, they got up and left. We followed suit and left with no apology from the manager. I'd hope they can plan ahead next time for a holiday weekend.

Had dinner here on a Saturday night. We sat at the bar which was perfectly fine as there were no available tables. 

I had the steak tacos and hubby had a cheeseburger with Mac and cheese as his side item. The meat in my tacos was underseasoned. Husband enjoyed his burger. The Mac and cheese was okay, but not spectacular. 

The atmosphere is very nice, and the bartenders were attentive. Other diners were offered popcorn while waiting for their food, though...not sure why we weren't offered any. We also got the feeling that they were trying to rush us out. 

I won't actively avoid returning here, but also won't go out of my way to come back. The overall experience was alright, but not worth the price.

Two stars this visit- both for the craft cocktail. Deviled eggs were dry and flavorless. Tuna tartare - devoid of anything that would make it unique. 
I guess the owners reap accolades for new restaurants, and hope the old tired ones can continue to ride on the coattails.
Ugh. Done with this place.

Good atmosphere and great mixed drinks. I have been here about five times and have never been blown away with the food and have always been disappointed with the price and small portions. I understand that meat is expensive, but is it really necessary to put child-sized portions of vegetables and other sides on the plate?

5 Church and Nan's is under the same ownership, and I would give the same review of both spots. These guys create great drinking places yet seem to fall short on the food.

I've been to Nan and Byron's several times and give them a solid 4 stars. Lunch is great - the meatloaf, tacos, French dip are all stellar. Their restaurant week menu was lovely. Brunch is a standard Charlotte brunch buffet, nothing too amazing there. But if you're looking for quality, no frills brunch convenient to the South End area - Nan and Byrons is worth a stop. As far as service goes: when they're good... they're GREAT, but it's been hit or miss in my experience.

I wanted to wait and give Nan & Byron's a fair shake and go a number of times, especially since I love their sister restaurant 5 Church. It has a very different vibe than 5 Church- a more casual, yet still hopping atmosphere with rustic interior touches. I've been here for cocktails, dinner and three times for lunch. It's totally appropriate for SouthEnd.

I highly endorse it for a place to meet friends for cocktails. Their cocktail/bar menu is inventive and delicious. The bartenders are pretty speedy and friendly. 

As Chad mentioned, the popcorn they give you is a nice way to give your mouth something to crunch on that I believe is nonfat (it's not oily, salty or buttery). It's a good thing because food comes out really really slowly and often not coordinated. In my experience if you have a table of 2, the meals come out at the same time. But if you have more than 2, it's your guess at what order/timing everything will come out. I don't mind that at a tapas place where you're sharing plates with friends, but in a business context where you have  a sandwich and someone else has another sandwich or salad and you're not sharing, it's polite to wait until everyone has their meal.  The other complaint I have about the timing is that the three times I've been for lunch have extended to a 2-hour lunch unnecessarily. Apparently you should announce a the beginning of the meal to your server that you need to get back to work. After about an hour and a half, the last time my coworkers and I had lunch, we asked for the check (even though we weren't done) because we had to get back to work and the server seemed genuinely surprised. Huh? It's a weekday, why wouldn't we have to go back to work??? It was bizarre. Anyway my point is, it's totally fine for a catch up lunch with a friend on a weekend, but beware of a long lunch if you're a working stiff. 

To the food... the peppadew poppers are really interesting and if you're willing to throw caution of calories to the wind, I highly endorse them.  The meatloaf is very grilled - I like the taste of it but the hubs did not. I appreciated the sriracha ketchup.  I do not really like the chicken- it runs very dry and the green beans I've had twice and both times they were over cooked.  If I were to go back for dinner I'd like to try the mushroom with quinoa or Tofu since their vegetarian entrees seem to be more interesting than their carnivorous ones.   For lunch, I definitely like the beet burger with boursin - it's my favorite thing on the menu. They brag about the farmhouse burger but there was something about it I didn't like. It was either the BBQ sauce or the poblano cheese, but the consistency and taste wasn't so good. Based on the wait my burger was "dying in the window" for a while and the cheese coagulated leaving a grainy, weird consistency. So my tip is definitely get the beet burger- you can't get that anywhere else, build your own burger. My friends really like the South End chicken hoagie too.  Though one time two of them got it and they came out at 2 different times and had different things on it. 

For dessert, the shortcake is very heavy. We were able to take 2 bites of it and the rest went uneaten. The PB&J was very interesting and different so my favorite of the two. Next time I'd try the brownie sundae with chili sauce. 

Bottom line- 2.5 stars - this is a place for cocktails or a place to go if you need something greasy, but just make sure you're not in a hurry or expect fantastic service.

This is the second time that I've gone to Nan & Byron's, once when they first opened and the second with a large party. In this review, we'll focus on the large party experience. 

This past friday night I was put in charge of organizing the dinner plans for a friend's 30th birthday dinner. My biggest pain point was the large party reservation process. First, when my reservation increased to over 10 people, I had to get in touch with the catering sales manager. The hosts on the phone would not take my reservation as they explained to me "they weren't allowed to". No problem. I can talk to someone else, but then I was expected to get in touch with that person, not the other way around, well it kinda ticked me off. Insert first pain point of customer service irritation. The next day that I called to change the reservation, I was instructed that once again "I" needed to get in touch with sales, and then I was informed that I would have to sign agreement, put a credit card on file and pay a $10 cover for any no shows. I get it - no shows and changes in reservations flat out suck, they do. However, when the most expensive entree on the menu is less than $20, I find this process a bit tough to swallow. Exhibit B of pain point. 

Now, after getting in touch with catering sales manager, I will say that she was very timely, professional and accommodating with the process. Not sure if this was on done on her behalf, but in lue of having to split up our tables inside the restaurant, we took the chances of sitting outside. Since we were gambling all our dinner plans around weather circumstances, the large party booking process was dismissed. Guess what... it turned out to be a glorious Charlotte evening. One that would have been perfect for sitting in the sweet Carolina air. Guess where my party sat... inside. After all the muss and fuss of not being able to find a table inside, that's exactly where we ended up. Strike 3! 

Moving on to the actual dining experience, our server was a doll. He took good care of us, kept the drinks flowing and timing was good except at the very end, when it took a solid 30+ minutes for checks and all. Food was average, drinks were yummy and decor was fab as always, but I certainly walked away feeling like I had just taken a big ol' swig of bitters from behind the bar. 

All and all, I might swing by for a lunch if that's where a friend wanted to eat, but it probably won't be on my list of recommendations anytime soon.

We sat outside for brunch. The staff was nice but the wait for food on Sunday's is forever! The kitchen gets backed up because of the buffet and a la carte. If you're looking for immediate food go with the brunch. 

I had the salmon Benedict (pretty small). The French toast is really good though but super sweet! 

I'd say the wait is why it loses a few stars and the Benedict wasn't super amazing.

I hate not giving this place a better review based on the food alone but I have to do it. The crispy beet burger is amazing! It's worth trying at least once. The issue I have is being overcharged. We ordered 2 cheeseburgers for the kids and got charged extra for cheese. We were also charged extra for ordering fruit as a side when it was listed on the kids menu as an option. It took us an additional 15 minutes to get the bill re-calculated so we could leave. The management needs to fix this. If things are extra, disclose it on the menu, or tell your waiters to disclose it.

I am absolutely outraged. I have been trying to get in contact with home office for weeks and when I've called people have been very rude and nasty. I've been a long time supporter of this company and after my experience at Nan And Byron's I don't know if I feel the same.
I visited the sister store a few weeks ago to test it out and the service was terrible. The management was rude and when I found hair in my food it was somehow my fault. 
I ordered the Cadillac margarita with a NY strip. The meal was fantastic until I noticed blonde hair in my meal. I'm a brunette. I told my server she was very apologetic. She sent over the female manager whose name I believe was Rachael. She acted very disinterested in helping. She said oh OK oh well I'll get you another one out. Being in the service industry myself I know that's not how your guest wants you to react. That was the issue the issue was I got charged for BOTH strips. When I pointed it out Rachel was really nasty and said she refused to take off the steak when most of it was eaten . ( The hair was at the other end! ) I paid and promised to never come back!
I'm really disappointed because uptown the service is incredible and I'm sad to possibly have to let go of a favorite restaurant.

Service is great here. Goes well with the whole southern hospitality theme. Food is alright. They brand themselves as an upscale brunch place but the presentation of the food not! 

Tip: Try and avoid ordering a cappuccino here.

I was on my way to Tupelo Honey, but they weren't open at 10:30 so I decided to stop in and check this place out instead.  I pulled on the fork and bellied up to the bar.  They had a good assortment of local beer and a friendly bartender.  I decided to skip the alcohol and went straight for the deviled eggs.  They tasted as I expected.  Nothing spectacular, but still hit the spot for deviled eggs.  The presentation was nice and they came out very quickly.  
For my entree I had the meatloaf sandwich with a side of mac and cheese.  The meatloaf sandwich was awesome with the spicy ketchup.  It was everything I expected and more.  Tender meatloaf on a delicious bun with spicy ketchup?  What isn't to like?

The mac and cheese?  I think there are as many mac and cheese recipes in the south as there are stars in the sky.  We all have a preference for a different type.  I personally prefer the big ziti-type noodle in bechamel type sauce with baked-on cheese on top...almost like a macaroni casserole.  This was almost the opposite.  The noodles were big spirals and were awesome, but the cheese was smooth like velveeta.  It still tasted good, but I prefer my Mac and Cheese to have a bit of personality.
The real star of the meal was the bartender who kept my tea constantly full.  Great service and good food = repeat business in my book.

Had my first experience tonight. The bartender and waiters were very attentive and seemed very knowledgeable about the menu. I do feel it was a little over priced but had a great variety to choose from. However, toward the middle of my meal I got a bad taste in my mouth. It wasn't the food.I witnessed someone I had not seen earlier talking to the employees as they were trying to accommodate a large party in the "garage room"  I guess that's what you can call it. Apparently, the tables were not done to this persons liking. At first I thought it was a customer not satisfied with the positioning of the tables. I sat there and listened to the way this person was speaking to the employees being very loud and rude. I looked around to see that other tables were listening as well. After I saw this person go to an empty table I realized he worked there. On my way to the restroom I stopped an employee and asked who it was. I was told it was the owner. I was shocked and even more shocked when I walked out of the bathroom and saw him leaning up against an empty bar table( at the front of the restaurant), checking his phone and eating what appeared to be a banana... I never once saw him check on a table. He could have but I never witnessed it in my 2 hours of being there. He certainly never asked us how we were doing. It's hard for me to want to return after seeing the way he treated his employees. This was enough for me to download yelp for the first time and give a review...

I really really really wanted to like this place, and I've been excited to finally try it.  The fella and I went on a Tuesday night and thought with the day (random Tuesday before Thanksgiving), time (8:00 pm) and weather (ungodly rain), it might be a little less crowded.  We were wrong.  Since I really did want to like this place, I'm going to start with the bad stuff so I can end on a good note.

THE BAD

Parking: The parking is still as annoying as it was with Vinnie's.  There's a valet, but he just directed me to a space coming available in the lot.  The fella wound up two blocks away in a random lot.

Hostess: We checked in at 7:55 for our 8:00 reservations.  The hostess acknowledged us, and then ignored us to answer the phone, which is one of my biggest restaurant pet peeves - always deal with paying customers first before answering the phone.  So, we checked in with the host.  Then the hostess seated two other groups.  We went back to the host, who apologized for the hostess and finally seated us.

Seating: If there are two of you, you'll get stuck a two-top table in the middle of everything and everyone.  The fella got bumped into countless times by waiters and patrons alike.  It's a flurry of activity, and it's cramped quarters.

Wine Glasses: So, the wine glasses look exactly like the water glasses but just a tiny smidgen smaller.  The fella wasn't impressed with the lack of wine glasses or the fact that the wine came in a glass that wasn't bowl-shaped.  He was even less impressed when the waiter accidentally refilled his wine glass with water.  Considering there was about one-fourth of the wine left, I was the least impressed (as the bill payer) when there was no comp on the wine... seriously?!?!  

THE GOOD

Food: Believe the hype about the peppedew popper appetizer ($5.50).  They're sweet and cheesy and delicious.  The meatloaf ($14.50) with sriracha ketchup was a great spicy twist on an old favorite.  (However, the mac & cheese and baked beans sides were just okay, and I didn't love that everything was stacked since my baked bean sauce kept getting mixed in with my meatloaf ketchup.)  The fella got the chicken ($14), which was a little dry but had a nice kick, and the slaw and mashed potato sides were excellent.

OVERALL

The fella has already said he'll never go again.  I'd try it once more just hoping that tonight was an off night, but... ugh.  At least get some real wine glasses!  Talk about squashed excitement.

My sisters and I had lunch reservation. We were greeted & seated immediately by a great staff. The food was undeniably delicious and we all loved our choices. A little bit on the pricier side but if you're okay with that, you won't be disappointed. I will definitely go to Nan & Byron's the next time I'm in town.

My wife and I made our first visit for lunch.   Arrived early,  seated promptly and server was pouring water within 2 minutes.   We split a club sandwich and mohito fries with a great dip and it was delicious.  Plus,  they offer Coke products!   My wife said it was the best sandwich she ever had!   Fair prices,  professional server,  casual atmosphere and exceptional food put this restaurant at the top of our recommend list.

Not sure what's up with the other negative reviews. My wife and I went the other night and loved it. Service was great, staff was friendly and everything was wonderful overall. The food was delicious. I had the pork chop and it was awesome. It was cooked perfectly and the grits it came on we're hands down best grits I have ever had. We will be back.

This is my new favorite restaurant...ever. It was so good that I can't wait to go back to Charlotte again. Really stellar beer selection and the burrata was out of this world good. I can't say enough good things about this place!!!!

Not exactly the best experience. My wife and I walked into N&B's about 7:30 Thursday evening.  We didn't have a reservation and the wait was about 45 minutes.  Not a big deal. 

We went to the bar to have a drink for the wait.  My wife had a couple of the mixed drinks on the menu, which she said were delicious, and I said were expensive ($9 & $10). We also had some popcorn while we waited, which was pretty good.

We took our seat around 8:10.  First negative - the table was right in the middle of the crowded bar area where dozens of people were standing on top of us.  If we had known that would be the table, we definitely would have opted to eat at the bar 45 mins earlier.

Second negative - we sat at our table for 18 mins before the server even came to take our drink/food order. Once we placed the order, it took an additional 13 mins to get our drinks (31 mins after we sat down).  The food came relatively soon afterward.

My wife had the mushroom and I created my own burger.  We both agree that although the food was good, it was nothing we would recommend. It also seemed a little pricey for what you actually got. 

Overall, not impressed.

The most lively restaurant any day of the week in Charlotte! You're guaranteed to have a delicious meal no matter what you order on the menu. I started with a caprese salad, followed by the beet burger, and finished with delicious strawberry shortcake. I thoroughly enjoyed my meal, the service I received, and the atmosphere. Definitely one of the best restaurants in Charlotte!

We tried Nan and Byron's tonight for the first time... the service was friendly and efficient.  The food was good...  I stepped away to use the ladies room and that's where the good review ends.  The room is very dark... tissue all over the floor... in the stall that i occupied there was no place to hang or put a handbag except the floor.  Though there is room for more than one sink, there was only one with a very small counter that was soaked.  A line waiting for the sink caused me to be very quick, but the room was too dark to reapply lipstick or comb hair and the counter way to wet to lean over for a closer look.  It never ceases to surprise me that the comfort and cleanliness of the bathroom is overlooked.

There isn't one thing I can complain about here. I'm grateful to have a new addition like Nan and Byron's in Charlotte. 

I recently had brunch at Nan's, which was exceptional. The smorgasbord was heavy on goods like crab legs and shrimp with grits and low on boring pastries. I sat outside on the patio, which is super cool with its funky garage doors. I've also had dinner here, which is just as great. I am absolutely in love with the beet burger, a refreshing treat for a pescetarian like me.  

All of the staff members are young, friendly and attentive. Definitely not any stuffiness here. So, if you're looking for superior food, a cool atmosphere and a trendy crowd/staff without the pretentiousness, you've stumbled upon the right spot. Can't wait to go back for brunch or dinner soon. P.S. - Don't miss the peppedew peppers as an appetizer. They are the most heavenly, creamy bites of deliciousness.

Me and my family came here for brunch on July 2nd. I really wanted Chicken and Waffles, but they didn't have that on the menu. They did have a buffet with sooooo many food choices. I could list it all...and I will! Pastries (muffins, scones, cookies, cupcakes), Grits, Silver Dollar Pancakes, Sausage, Eggs, Bacon, Fried Chicken, Home Fries, Carved Beef, Gravy and Biscuits, Salad Bar, Crab Legs, Oysters, Macaroni and Cheese...that's just a little over half of the items. lol

Anywho...Everything was absolutely AMAZING! I will be back soon! Oh...Service was great! I wish I could remember my server's name. Overall...A+

Service was spotty and perhaps the staff was overwhelmed by Queens Feast reservations (this place was not packed) but our server didn't understand the menu and how to add drinks on our tab. 

The popcorn they put on the table was burnt and the tomato soup was very very salty.

My pork chop dish was way undercooked (pork should not be raw in the middle nor on the ends. I sent it back and they cut off the ends that were raw and bought it back. Sad.

I ordered a side of Mac and cheese for the table and it never came. I ordered a second cocktail and the confused waitress said it would not be at the special pricing so what other liquor would I like in the tropical mule, rum was my answer and charge me for the regular cocktail. This place didn't even promote special cocktail prices on their Queen Feast menu so maybe the staff should just say: if you would like a cocktail off the invisible QF menu its regular pricing. Easy 

The ppl next to us were in mid entree and our desserts were delivered to their table. Just a big old cluster fuck. I've had my eye on this place for awhile and it was disappointing to have this experience. One and done.

Our waitress was lovely, but the wait time was outrageously long. The restaurant had emptied out before our dinner arrived--I think we waited over an hour. The food was not that good... My chicken taco was so dried out that the meat was crunchy and flavorless. This is not our first time waiting forever and then getting so-so food, so I'm finally leaving a review.
Fun atmosphere, great food and the service is perfect!  Popcorn to get you started and the chicken soup is nothing like grandma's!

What a fun birthday celebration! I had only been to N&B's for a Yelp event, so I was excited to actually have a dinner. We grabbed a table outside, which is quite pleasant even though you're basically in the parking lot. The entire night our server was on point. She was friendly, but not too much, quick and helpful when it came to offering up dinner suggestions. The manager even came over to check on our meal. We made reservations and ate early, around 6:30. I would recommend this, considering this place tends to get busy. I really like the decor of N&B's- cozy with a twist. 
Now on to the food... 
We all ordered the red wine blend that was on special, perfect way to start off the night, follow by their complementary popcorn... spicy and a little odd, but not bad, just not expected. We ordered the poblano cheese dip. Wow, It's heavy like you would expect and served with homemade chips, the only problem, you may completely ruin your appetite with this appetizer. 

On to the main dishes- Between the meatloaf, tacos and my pork chops, everything was great. Heavy southern dishes all with a modern add on spicy grits and salmon tacos. The only downside, the majority of the menu was very heavy. I didn't think they had a lot of lighter options to choose from. The menu is a little on the pricier side- ranging from 18-30 dollars for an entrée, but I do think the pricing is justified. 

The night was sealed with a sweet treat of turtle Cheesecake, on the house.... What a nice surprise, they even wrote Colin a birthday card and gave up a coupon for a return visit. Damn, that is some good marketing!

The service is absolutely terrible: hostesses didn't greet us, our waiter (or I would say bartender because it sounds that they only have bartenders and bus man) give our table to someone else, explaining that his shift his over (the most unprofessional behavior that I've never seen) and our new waitress was very rude and couldn't figure it out what we ordered so we have to repeat again everything.... In addition she removes our plates without asking us anything... If I give 1 star it's because the food was okay, we get the scallops, mac and cheese and sweet potato but the desserts was absolutely disgusting (cheesecake and apple tart). So please stay away from the restaurant, for the same price you can find a better service and better food aswell. I am not usually a picky person but this restaurant is absolutely a mess, and of course we won't come back.

We had a pleasant dinner here recently. The waiter was very nice and the food was delicious! We started with the Peppedew Poppers. They needed a little something extra, like maybe a bit of goat cheese or some spicy heat. But, I love peppers and they were perfectly crispy! We split the chicken and the pork chop. Both were really very good. The bacon & blue cheese popover that accompanies the chicken was flavorful and baked just right. The cheddar-jalapeno grits that accompany the pork chop... I could have eaten a bowl of them by themselves!

Had dinner here for the first time last night.  Food was amazing.  Great drink menu and solid beer selection.  The beer menu is not vast by any stretch but the few they have are very good- lots of local brews too.  
Started out with deviled eggs and cheese dip apps. Eggs were good.  The cheese dip was unbelievable.  Couldn't stop eating it.  Had the Farmhouse Burger as my entree. Very good!  cooked perfectly- very rich burger so try not to eat eggs and cheese dip before you order the burger. Service was great

The decor was really cool.  I had flashbacks of the old decrepit Vinny's.  What an amazing transformation.

Went here last night with my girl for dinner. The food was great! we got several dishes and split them so that we could try a bunch of different stuff. Our favorites were the poppers and the meatloaf, but everything was delicious. This is a great local spot with a very unique vibe and design. We will definitely be coming back many times.

The saltiest bite of food I've ever had...yuck!!!

I won't be going back.  Taste your food, chef...c'mon!

Fun atmosphere but I was disappointed in the Sunday brunch. For $23, I would liked to have seen homemade pastries, lots of fresh berries, something inventive rather than plain scrambled eggs, home fries, hotel standards. etc. Upsides are the pimento cheese, and if you like cold steamed shrimp and crab legs. I'll definitely come back to try the non brunch menu. Tip... Don't expect mimosas before noon. State law. Looks like the place would be more fun in the evening when candles are lit and the glass garage door is thrown open for a more indoor, outdoor setting.

We went with a family group of 8 to Sunday Brunch this past weekend. The food was amazing. When we arrived, even with our reservation, we were put on a waiting list. After waiting for 15 minutes, we inquired about the wait, and the hostess was a bit snarky. But, the manager came to the rescue and made things right immediately.
Tiny little issue aside, the food was great and the manager checked on us frequently and provided us with free desserts. The desserts were amazing. Their take on "oreo" cookies and milk was a breath of fresh air! Amazingly delicious. 
All of the food was fantastic. We will definitely be returning to try dinner!

I haven't written a bad review in a long time, but Nan and Bryon's is just asking for it. 

I'm with a group of friends and decided on Nan and Bryon's after a stop at the new dog bar (Lucky Dog). We called and there was no wait on a Saturday night, which was the prime selling point (perhaps a red flag as well). 

They sat us quickly and I settled on the shrimp and grits. The waitress completely sold us on it and sadly, a complete let down. The portion is tiny and the grits were hard and absolutely terrible. I finished the shrimp and andouille sausages because I was starving. Afterwards, I'm still starving! I was concerned about the portion size and even asked the waitress. She said she would be able to provide a side if we need it, which is great. Unfortunately, she never asked and never came back! The bf got the "chicken pot pie," also flavorless and not at all special. On top of that, both of our meals were over $20. I much rather go to Cluck N Cup down the street for my chicken pot pie ($7!) and basically anywhere else for shrimp and grits. 

The last time I was here I ordered a medium rare steak. Instead, I got well done. I sent it back and they came back with rare. I kept it because again, starving. I think I've given nan and Bryon's enough chances. Sorry, not sorry.

Trying new places during restaurant week can always be hit or miss. Nan and Byron's is a big HIT! Excellent staff, we let them know it was an anniversary, they noted it, sent champagne , an anniversary card and small app. Of marinated strawberry and cheese , small touches that made an impression before the food even hit the table and The food was incredible! We had the crispy oysters app, the hanger steak  and the scallops both came with creative side dishes loaded with flavor. Along with its very comfortable (on a hot humid night) indoor outdoor dinning areas it was a HIT all around . Already looking forward to going back with friends.

Wow. What a disaster. 

We were sat by the service station. A broom handle loomed over my head. The place was not even a fifth full. It was brunch and we chose the buffet.

At the buffet, every single plate was wet. Not slightly damp, but covered in water. The plates are right next to the host station, I guess that everyone stationed there chose not to notice us wiping our plates dry.

The pastries were cut into smaller pieces (quartered, etc) and dry. The potatoes had so much salt on them, it burned my tongue. And the oysters on the half shell!!! Whoa. They had "melted"- flattened out and filled the shell and now had a firm texture. In a word- disgusting.

I covered my mostly untouched food with a napkin, the waitress asked if I wanted another plate for the buffet. Uh, no.

Never again.

I am going to return to Nan & Byrons, because I know they deserve another shot, but this experience was a little "meh".

We stopped in for sunday brunch before noon, with a reservation, hoping we'd miss a bit of the crowd. They sat five of us on a four-top that barely had room for four once you add in the amount of beverages usually consumed at breakfast (water/tea or coffee/juice), but we managed. 

I ordered an orange juice first, then my sister ordered an orange juice a few minutes later. Mine came in a tall glass with ice and by the looks of it looked fresh squeezed (or I was hoping that's what the separation of water and juice meant) hers arrived in a short glass without ice, perfectly mixed together.

Our server had never worked a brunch before so she couldn't answer any questions about the menu. She also didn't know how to add an egg to a breakfast (someone wanted three eggs, only two arrived on the plate), and when someone wanted their eggs "well done" (half jokingly), she never clarified and just rang them in as over easy. I asked if the side of fruit was just a simple market diced melon/pineapple blend and she said yes, actually it comes with yogurt and granola on top. Not the end of the world for me, but some people might not want that. 

My mother's entree came out with a few of the appetizers, so when we were all eating our main dishes my mother was left eating her tiny side of garlic shrimp. It was a little sad. While she was (slowly) eating her shrimp, my fiance was attempting to eat his charred, dried up sausage, I was trying to figure out how one of my eggs was barely poached while the other was a solid mass (I can't even say poached "hard", it was further gone than that) on top of my barely warm beet benedict, and another guest was a little hungry without his third egg and had to ask for a side of sriracha ketchup three times. 

Yes, I loved the beets. I want to order them again, but I want them to be hot. I'd even take luke-warm. The french toast went over well. There were some highlights, but almost $20/person without a beverage for brunch demands more, especially being charged for the sriracha ketchup. 

And does anyone know what the donation line is for on the bill? Who am I donating to?? There wasn't any information about it anywhere, and that seems weird to me.

This was the one pick of our restaurant week selections that I was most excited about. Loved the decor and the feel of the interior. We got there before the big crowd so it was laid back relaxed and pretty quiet. The servers were on top of their game and the courses were served and a perfect pace. There was no rush to get us in and fed and out. 
We had the oysters and the Cobb salad for starting course. That was the beast Cobb I've ever had anywhere. The oysters were good but were just odd to handle. The pineapple base they have is a great compliment to the heat of the Jalapeño.
Main courses.....we had the pan seared chicken and the NY strip. The chicken and green beans were perfectly cooked, the Gorgonzola popover was over cooked and rubbery, blueberry marmalade was good though. My honey's steak was good not great and the fries were a little dry. 
Desserts.....lord have mercy. Ok one of the reasons I wanted to put N&B's on the list of to do's was to try the banana pudding. Ate the whole flipping thing and dared my honey to take one solitary bite. Not really but yeah it was goooooood. I got a taste of his Key Lime tart, they aren't kidding about the tart part. Tart part...hahahaa sorry I thought it was funny. 
Anywho, the guy and I have decided that this place will def be a do over spot. Try it out the food is really good and the prices on the regular menu aren't all that bad any day.

The decor is low-key, sedate.  I really like how the entrance is open and inviting.  They mentioned they are going to do a patio area going from the building out towards the street.  It sounds awesome, but parking is already a bit tight (though they do offer valet), so that might be an issue for some.

We were there early for a quick appetizer right after work and so it was quiet still.  I don't know that I'd be happy dining there when it's super crowded in the bar area.  Although there is a wall between the dining and bar areas, it is partitioned in a way there would still be a ton of noise.

We enjoyed the food and the servers and staff were all friendly and made us feel welcomed and comfortable.

The food selection seemed good with good wine selections.

This was my third time here. We went for lunch at an off time so it was very quiet in the restaurant. 

They provide a basket of some spicy popcorn while you wait for your food. Yum. Make sure you have some water on hand  if spice gets you. 

This particular visit I went for the salmon soft tacos. They came with more than enough lettuce, tomato, the most delicious guacamole and cheese for days. The flavor on the salmon was perfect and I was more than full as you get three tacos. 

My friend got the turkey club and loved it. 
She also got some salted caramel dessert, which I snuck a bite, and it was ohmygod good. 

I love this place. I love the country chic decor. It's casual and comfy. 

The only issue I had was.. It was dead and our server wasn't the most attentive. She was just standing around talking while we waited for water refills. I'm not one who needs much - but I could see this being an issue if it were busier.  

Overall- I would most definitely go back!

Definitely try the Farmhouse Lemonade, and the smoked pork spring roll!  Both are delicious!  My husband had the seared tuna and I had the Hanger steak and we both enjoyed them.  For dessert, I had the Chocolate torte, he had the banana pudding, and both were delicious!  Looking forward to returning to try more!

Nan and Byron's is my new favorite restaurant in the Southend. Everyday I drive past it and have wanted to go in. This weekend I finally got the chance. We showed up about 45 minutes early for our reservation so we just hung out at the bar and got some drinks. When we got seated we were put in the outdoor area that had a tent over it and some heat lamps. It was very crowded in the restaurant since it was the Saturday of Valentine's Day weekend, but it was freezing in the tent. We asked if we could move tables once we sat down because we all had to sit there in our winter coats to be even remotely warm. They moved us to a table that was still in the tent but closer to a heat lamp. While it was a bit warmer i definitely would have preferred to be inside since it was only 30 degrees out. That is where my complaints stop for Nan and Byron's though. 
We started our meal with the Sushi Grade Tuna Tartare to split between the three of us and it was fantastic. I don't like Tuna Tartare when it is ground up but this was cubed tuna and was very buttery and delicious. It was a perfect palate cleanser to start the meal. I had heard wonderful things about their popcorn so we asked our waitress for some because it didn't look like they were giving it to everyone. It completely lived up to the hype. I would have never thought to put Cayenne on popcorn but now i can't see eating it without it. I ordered the Spiced Prime Bistro (medium rare), my dad got the C.A.B. Filet Mignon (medium rare), and my mom got the Pan Roasted Chicken Pot Pie. While ordering my dad also asked for a small Caesar salad but it never came. By the time we realized it never came we were already halfway through the meal and didn't think it was worth the trouble. My Spiced Prime Bistro was great. My only complaint about it was that it was a bit more medium than medium rare. The potatoes were to die for though. I could have made those my entire meal. My dad's C.A.B. Filet was also great and so was the Pan Roasted Chicken Pot Pie. The puff pastry was an awesome substitute to the normal pie crust for chicken pot pie. Like I said this is a great restaurant and I can't wait to go back!

I am not impressed with this place at all. We ordered the mussel appetizer which tasted odd. Service was great and the manager took the appetizer back and came back to tell us that the chef agreed. However by that time I didn't want to try anything else so we finished our glass of wine and left.

I always recommend Nan & Byron's when asked about good Charlotte restaurants. My husband and I keep coming back here. The ambience and style is great and love the outdoor seating option. One of our favorite things is the popcorn starter. So delicious and unique. We've had the meatloaf, pan roasted chicken, steaks, and an amazing poblano cheese dip starter that is no longer on the menu. Never a bad meal and always nice service!
Did brunch at Nan & Bryon's.  Basic brunch w/seafood at a reasonable price.

What an utter disappointment. The dinner was mediocre, but the service... the service was truly the worst I've experienced in years. There were only a few other tables in the restaurant, but our server disappeared for long stretches of time, and when we finally could get our check, there were so many errors and upcharges. I had to request that she remove an entree we hadn't ordered, and she added various upcharges that weren't accurate. I'd heard good things about the restaurant and had high hopes, but I wouldn't visit here again.

My wife and my daughter and I gave Nan & Byron's a try for their Sunday Brunch buffet. Nice selection with a few of the usual items - scrambled eggs, sausage links, bacon, biscuits, grits - and a few that were a bit more unusual including a huge tray of oysters, large shrimp, meatloaf squares and a good few things made with sweet potatoes.

I particularly enjoyed the shrimp (with a New Orleans remoulade, but would have preferred a classic cocktail sauce) and the sweet potato au gratin. Sliced salmon was good too, but I didn't really feel like waiting for the toaster to toast.

Service was okay with a waiter who refilled Diet Coke often but coffee not as much. I think he was maybe disappointed that we didn't go all in for the refillable mimosas or bloody marys. We're not all booze drinkers, ya know?

Parking's challenging with a small lot but there are some spots to be found on the street.

I really wanted to love Nan and Byron's. It's a hip restaurant that has made a name for itself in the Charlotte dining scene. Unfortunately it has been a let down the two times I've gone. The first time was for dinner and the experience was "okay". I ordered one of their chicken dishes and some other fusion appetizer. There was a long wait to receive our meals and when it arrived the dishes were just merely acceptable--if anything, rather boring. 

This second time I wanted to give the restaurant another try. I was hopeful that it would be as good as what everyone has hyped it up to be. Unfortunately the results of my visit were much worse than the first. From their dinner menu I ordered their Tuna Tartar (raw) and their Braised Lamb (medium rare). These are two risky but common dishes, and if done well, are usually quite wonderful. Unfortunately one (or both) of these dishes gave me food poisoning later on. Nothing severe, but unpleasant to say the least. Not sure what went wrong there, but I can say the lamb was a rubbery mess that was hardly edible and something I really should've sent back to the kitchen.

The service also did not improve the second time around. The wait was even longer for something less than satisfactory. The only redeeming factor of my visit was the Banana Pudding for dessert which was surprisingly good. It's a shame everything else wasn't. I can assure you there won't be a third try.

We went to Nan And Bryon's this past Sunday for brunch. Still adjusting from my move to Charlotte from Florida, I was disappointed to be reminded that mimosas and bloody mary's won't be served until 12; we were there at 11. The buffet purchase includes a mimosa, bloody mary, or other drink. Regardless, we both elected to do the brunch buffet as the menu looked solid. Once at the buffet line, I grabbed a little bit of everything: smoked salmon, scrambled eggs, bacon, sausage gravy with a biscuit, a deviled egg, a small veggie frittata, cavatappi (seafood) pasta salad, a fresh oyster, and bacon mac and cheese. Everything was good, but nothing jumped out as a spectacular item. I was full from my plate but would have gone back for more bacon mac and cheese if I had room. I wouldn't have valued the meal at $21, especially since the alcoholic drink wasn't included in our visit.

What happened to Nan and Byron's??  The first few times I visited, shortly after they opened, the food was good and the atmosphere was fun.  However, of late every time I have been I have been so disappointed.  I had tomato soup that tasted like marinara sauce and grilled cheese that was nothing special.  The cocktails are nice but the place is so empty it's not a great scene.  They have such a great location and great decor, I hope they can turn it around!

I had an opportunity to get here a few weeks ago and better-yet twice within that one week. My first visit was centered around the bar as the plan was to check out the atmosphere of what appeared to be the new hot spot restaurant in South End. Having just recently moved from Uptown to a South End I was anxious to see what the fellas from 5 Church had going on. 

Snagging a spot at the corner of the bar offered a great view of a pretty busy restaurant for a weekday. The bar tenders were attentive and friendly even considering a full bar. After 30 minutes or so I I had to take a peak at the menu and decided that contrary to my initial plan of "drinks only" I was going to grab something small. Now, when a restaurant aims for what it appears Nan and Byron's is aiming for I like to give a good test of the menu and order something a bit atypical. That said, by offering a hot dog and mac and cheese a place like this I couldn't pass this opportunity up. It wasn't even on the kid's menu! Let's be honest, if you can nail a hot dog and mac and cheese at what appears to be a quality restaurant than more power to ya. Certainly I agree that with this order I couldn't have possibly expected much, but again, it is Nan and Byron's that offered it and so I had to take them up on it. 

Unfortunately I was pretty disappointed. I can't complain much about the value as these were some of the less expensive items on the menu but I can certainly complain of the quality. Honestly, if you are going to go out on a limb by offering a hot dog at a place like this then I'd expect you would at least reward the customer daring enough to order it. The presentation itself was good but the flavor wasn't much greater than what you'd expect from your most basic hot dog. When I asked the bar tender what we were dealing with she admitted she thinks it is a Nathan's hot dog...boiled! Not grilled, but boiled. Who in their right mind boils a Nathan's frank! As for the mac and cheese I can't really speak much about it; not much to write home about and although creamy couldn't help but think "Velveeta". I'm sure it wasn't and maybe I'm more of a baked mac and cheese guy but this wasn't doing it for me. 

Although I will admit this isn't the end of the world for food delivered to my bar stool but I don't think I would be happy if I placed this order from a table. However, this is the point of the experiment, no? Try something from the menu so atypical that likely very few people would order it in an attempt to test the integrity of the one who decided to place the item on the menu to begin with. It is that mindset that brought me back to Nan and Byron's for "round 2" less than a week later to try something more typically ordered.

On my second visit I decided to go for more or the full experience; grab a table and order something more typical. When my girlfriend and I arrived it was Friday around 9:30pm. Upon entering we were greeted by the hostess who was quick to ask us if we had a reservation. I thought it was strange to ask considering the number of tables available. Since we of course didn't have a reservation the hostess asked us to take a seat to wait for the next available table. Now, I'm not sure if this was a ploy to make them seem busier than they were or possibly an attempt to limit the workload on their staff. Either way it is always frustrating to wait for a table when 1) you are only a party of two and 2) you can see empty tables. At the end of the day it wasn't more than a 15 minute wait so not a huge deal. 

Once we were seated I began to take in the atmosphere itself. The setup of the restaurant is great and the design is appealing. I can see this place being a good go-to for a casual date night. As per my previous experience I can attest to the friendliness of the bartenders and could see a drink or two first at the bar before grabbing a table for dinner being a great date experience. Additionally, who could say anything bad about the decision to serve fresh popcorn in place of the old standby bread? Who doesn't love popcorn?!? By the time the waiter took his second pass we were ready to order and I went with his recommendation which was the meatloaf while my girlfriend went with a standard cheese burger. The meatloaf was okay in that the consistency was good, not dry etc. Serving size was good and the roasted corn was very good thought maybe a bit "too roasted" with some bites. However, although I can understand the difficulty in getting the spices right in a meatloaf it truly had waaaay too much rosemary in it. Unfortunately the overwhelming flavor of the rosemary overpowered any other possible flavors and made for a less than perfect experience. The mashed potatoes had some pretty good flavor but were cold in both my order and my girlfriends.

I can't say I wont be back here but I'm certainly not going to rush back. I think this place is certainly worth a shot and with a few tweaks can easily bring my rating up to a 4-star.

Went back to this restaurant for the first time since opening week and was extremely disappointed. The service was slow and unpleasant. The food was average at best. The manager on duty kept hovering over the bartender with an attitude. I talked this place up and to boot my friend felt ill the rest of the night after eating here. I will not go back again.

Great selection at the bar. I tried a rum drink but the lemonade looked delicious. Customer service was top notch. Kitchen closed at 10pm and we got there just 20 min before. I ordered the mushroom ravioli. I love how the flavor of the mushrooms really pop out. The white cream sauce was kinda salty. The peas helped the flavor. My friend got the steak salad and said it was perfect. The steak was medium rare and flavorful with a tangy mix of dressing and fresh greens. The decor was nice, lighting soft. They have a mix of high tables, booths and regular tables. On cold evenings don't sit by the front. The large glass doors allow a lot of the cold in when opened. They had a beer garden in the back. I'd come back just to try the many options on the cocktail list.

My husband and I are visiting my cousin I'm Charlotte and decided to come here before hitting up some of the local breweries. The food was AMAZING! We had popcorn to start and I had the prosecco mojito which was good but sweet. I ended up ordering the shrimp n grits which was divine. There were plenty of shrimp, not too much grits and the sauce and seasoning was great. Would highly recommend.

The only reason I am not giving 5 stars is because after we got our food we literally didn't see our waitress for the rest of the time. We waited for about 30 minutes which was fine because we were talking and the bartender had to go get our check. Service wasn't the best.

Don't get the buffet brunch. Definitely not worth 23 bucks. I found the food to be sub-par, you get one drink, and not a big selection. We should've ordered  off the regular menu . The food looked fresher, obviously. But then again, I'm a picky bitch. You all might love it. Ok, the "sausage gravy" tasted odd with NO sign of sausage anywhere. Scrambled eggs looked dry, "homefries potatoes" were bland and tasteless and weren't homefries, they were roasted potatoes,
That's all. The shrimp was pretty good and the sauces were tasty. I didn't try the crab legs. The sticky buns were broken up and  liquidied in a sugary, Carmelized sauce and they were FUCKIN SCRUMPTIOUS !! Best thing, I thought. They had cheese and fruit, blah blah. I don't eat that shit for breakfast. I need bacon and eggs, and all that.  For me, because I prefer typical breakfast food, it wasn't worth the price and the quality suffers. I wouldn't go back. My fat ass is till trying to get into the Tupelo Honey Cafe!!'

Went here during restaurant week. Lots of things to like about this place: valet parking, pleasant hostess, nice decor. It was too cold, but they appear to have a pretty sizable patio area which I'm sure would be great in warmer months.

I had the sweet potato soup to start, which was topped with sour cream. I wouldn't mind the sour cream as a decorative glaze, but it was entirely too much. Made the soup too bitter when mixed. For the main course, I asked for the Wagyu flank, medium rare. Definitely came out much closer to rare. I didn't send it back because our server was pretty busy, so didn't want to be a pain in the neck. But yeah, they definitely undercooked it. The dish comes with a sauteed broccolini which really underwhelmed in terms of taste. No butter or salting. Sort of just plain broccoli.

I think this place is close to four stars, but needs some improvements. If they can cook the meat closer to order, not overdo it on the sour cream, and add some taste to the broccoli, I'd add a star. Overall, though, a nice spot to grab a bite.

The rudest staff I've encountered at a restaurant! The hostess was quite possibly the rudest girl I've ever encountered!!! We did the brunch buffet at 12p which was a huge disappointment. They ran out of biscuits, deviled eggs, potatoes.... No fruit. What actually was on the buffet was cold and not good. Not worth the $25....

NOTE TO MANAGER** you need to train your staff to warn customers if the plates are 500 degrees when they put them down in front of them! I have bad blistering after lightly touching the plate to scoot it over and it would have been easy for her to have said "Ladies, these plates are hot so don't touch!" The plates were just waaaay too hot anyway. All 3 of our meals looked like the been sitting under a heat lamp for 10 min. And did we get free anything for that? No, just mustard to put all over it to take the pain away.

On separate note, we came for Queens Feast at 6:30 and you'd think they'd want to get us in and out as things got busier. Basically the service just slowed to a hault by 7 and we waited forever to get our meals and drinks. We even had to take our desert to go. And the deserts were pitiful. Key lime pie was supposed to have berries - but none. Smores cheesecake had a lightly browned marshmallow on top of regular cheesecake - pitiful. Although shrimp and grits was good, none of us will be back.

Had been waiting for them to open for a few months after following their posts on FB, etc. Went there on a Friday night after them being open for only a week. I can say it lived up to my expectations.

The menu was somewhat limited, but what they had all looked good. They started the table out with some popcorn instead of customer bread, chips, etc. It was great. I believe it was just regular popcorn with a light sprinkle of cumin. Very subtle, very good.

We had the dry rubbed wings as an app, they were also very good. 

For entrees. we had the pork (pork shoulder) and shrimp (over pasta). Both were very good. The only possible negative is that the entrees ( at least some of them) don't come with any sides. The side looked good, but were ala carte.

Not to be left out were the drinks. They were quite interesting - more craft than your normal fare. My wife had the Nightshade (actually two) and I had a local craft beer. All good.

Service was quite good, especially for a brand new place. All the inevitable kinks were worked out.

Overall N&B's lived up to my expectations and is a welcome addition to South End. We'll be back regularly.

Went on opening weekend, valet told us "good luck" getting a seat w/o a reservation. There were 10 open tables!
First off, all their cocktails are $10 and I don't mind paying that for a good one, but they MEASURED each pour of alcohol in each drink. It would take me $100 to catch a buzz.
We got the mac and cheese (tasted like velvetta), chicken breast (very bland and dry), and recommended French dip (no).  The best part of the whole meal was the Wasabi dipping sauce for the fries (not saying much). I'm not one to write a bad review, but this place did not impress.

Eh. We left dinner with a blah attitude about this restaurant. There was nothing special about the food or the service. Most of the food was bland and we were served burnt popcorn. I expect to be wow'd by food when paying $20 for an entree.

Worst drinks and food that I've had in Charlotte in years. If you love hot drinks and cold food this is your spot!!! The manager did take care of somethings to try to fix what the kitchen had so badly messed up. You would think when a table went so wrong they may not charge you for mustard but nope they charged us. Waitress was very sweet but needs a bit more training. All in all a waist of an evening.

First time for the brunch and was impressed given it was their first day serving brunch. 

Omelette was very good with fresh quality ingredients. Portobello mushrooms, fresh kale and tomatoes. Rye toast was very good as well. 

Only complaint would be the extra charges for jelly and hot sauce. That should be provided with the meal. 

I will be back!

This is the second time to Nan and Byrons, both for brunch.  The first time was phenomenal, today was the exact opposite.  Had a reservation for 1:15 and did not get sat... ever.  Ended up eating at the bar (BARTENDERS WERE AWESOME).  I have managed restaurants in New York City prior for 7 years and have never had an owner place the blame on patrons.  After inquiring about when we would be sat the third time.. the owner "apologized" and by that i mean said sorry but you did add two people to your reservation.... In fact what he had done was place the blame on us.. at this point we had been waiting an hour past our reservation time.  He offered no drinks, no table, no solution.  Will not be returning and will be spreading the word throughout the race community as well.

Nan's is my new favorite restaurant in Charlotte. I've eaten here several times I have never been disappointed. My friends and I like to go for dinner and drinks and stay and hang out at the bar after. I have also brought friends from out of town here, and will be bringing my parents when they come to visit. The restaurant is warm and inviting, and the energy is always up no matter what time of day it is. Sometimes it takes a minute to get your table (and yes, you need a weekend dinner res), but once you're seated the service is FAST. I have been to nan's several times and I am still noticing new things about the décor. It is clean and modern but has a lot of rich, interesting touches. From the ceiling to the floors, they did a great job...seriously, look up when you're in there :)

So far I've had the kitchen sink salad, added chicken with the siracha ranch. It was awesome...its not exactly a healthy salad (it has chips on it) but it was delicious & different. I've also had the chicken, got the mashed potatoes and corn as my sides. One of my favorite meals. The appetizers are great - peppadew poppers and train wreck fries are my favorites. My friends are still raving about how good the meatloaf is. 

The drinks are very different - they put a unique twist on classic cocktails. I've tried the Jalapeno margarita, sparkling mojito, farmhouse lemonade, g'night moon, and the refashioned. I like all of them - favorite is the refashioned, and my girlfriends are huge fans of the lemonade and mojito. The margarita has a little kick to it but just enough.

On weekend nights the bar scene is pretty good. A lot of locals from the south end come in and the crowd is casual yet classy. Saturday nights there's a DJ and I've seen a few dance parties breakout...its always a good time. 

Overall, I love this place, and I'm excited for the warm weather - looking forward to enjoying drinks and food out on the patio. Glad the south end got such a wonderful new addition!

I love the southern style menu here. The inside is rustic, yet intimate. Their food is one of a kind, and I love that they have deviled eggs on their appetizer list. Definitely somewhere everyone needs to try. Great drink list as well!

Fun lunch and not so crowded or noisy that you could not hear one another. Very pleasing experience.  Loved the atmosphere, and the cuban sandwich was great.  The starter popcorn that they offer is wonderful.  Wish I had the recipe!  Service was wonderful and the restaurant was very clean and we thoroughly enjoyed our visit.  Cleanest bathrooms I have seen in a restaurant!

went there for first time earlier in the week for lunch and it was great- enjoyed it so much that I made resv. for my kids and hubby for Sunday Brunch- it was Extremely disappointing- a waste of money-
 flies were landing on food- a lot of it was undercooked and   getting servers to wait on us at the start took 10 min. to get a glass of water and a greeting from someone-
 it was not even busy then. was not worth the 24 bucks per person.
  Nan and Byrons  can do good food, but Sunday brunch is not  when  they. are doing  it..... don't try to do clever "riffs" on classic dishes- just please do them well and pay attention to them....

We went here for the first time on 9/8/15 
I will never go back!!! The service was very unprofessional. We ask for dirty martinis and they tasted like dirty soap water.

Jamie, if you want your business to continue, you should teach your staff how to be professional and courteous to the customers that are walking through your door.

And just a side-note, I was born and raised in the Dilworth area so I know the changes that have and are happening and this place will not survive. I don't care how many restaurants you own.

As a realtor I would not recommend this place to anyone!

Nan and Byron's has excellent food, a well-trained and friendly staff, and a fun atmosphere.  I went on Tuesday night with friends and ordered the hushpuppies to start, which arrived absolutely delicious--perfectly fried with honey butter on the side.  I ordered the beet burger as my main course, and as a vegetarian who has encountered many "veggie" burgers, this one blew my mind. The burger arrived on a perfect brioche bun, smeared with avocado (my favorite). The beets stole the show, lightly coated in panko breadcrumbs and fried to achieve that perfect crunch when bitten into. I even tried dessert- strawberry shortcake, which was equally amazing!  I'll definitely be back!

My sweaty yoga girls and I came for brunch again on Sunday 17 Jan... we had a VERY good experience, service-wise, and thoroughly enjoyed the brunch buffet!  Thank you to our sweet server, and the gracious hostess who took care of us!

Brunch is Awesome. You can choose from salads to meatloaf and shrimp with grits to crab legs and french toast. It was wonderful. Panthers game was on too and it was nice with the garage door open. My 3rd visit and I am always suprised.

Came here for restaurant week and was so disappointed. Got sat an hour after our reservation and the only reason I am giving it 2 stars is because they did a phenomenal job with trying to make sure we were taken care of. That being said the food was meh.....I have heard the same from a lot of ppl and told myself I would give it a try. The atmosphere is nice but I don't think it's worth the money food wise.

We were in from out of town and reviewed several article for the best places to go for brunch. Nan and Byron's was one of the five or so that consistently were on all of the lists. They had a very good variety of items on the brunch buffet, including vegetarian options. The sweets were very good. Come of the salads on the average side. A couple of stir fry options that were there I can't comment on because they were near empty when we checked them out at 1130, and they were still next to empty not having been refilled the entire time of our stay. The best item on the buffet was the fried chicken to be honest. I really would have expected the buffet to have been a bit better than this for it to have been on the top ten of every list we looked at, perhaps it was an off day for them I don't know.

Did you say farm to table?  Why yes I did.  Did you say indoor seating that slides open on warm days? Why yes I did. Did you say they use interesting flavors and textures on their menu like chicken wings glazed with ghost peppers in honey mustard sauces and crispy cornmeal fried beat sandwiches topped with a avacado and boursin cheese on a brioche bun? What about the timid folks what will they eat? Burgers, steak, meatloaf,  chicken, ok. What's for dessert?  Fudge brownie topped with coffe ice cream and Ancho chocolate Chile sauce. OK. When can we go?

I stopped in here for brunch one day with my husband and could not believe the spread for the buffet they had. I was sick that day and not feeling like eating a whole lot or I would have gotten it for myself. The buffet included a drink such as a mimosa or bloody mary and of course the entire buffet which had crab legs! The price was $21 which is good when you consider one drink is about $8-10 anyway. My husband ordered it and went back several times. They had a great selection of items. I ordered an omelette and the hash browns were delicious with good spice. 
I can't wait to go back for dinner one night.

We've been meaning to have dinner or brunch here for quite a while, but just never got around to it.  We finally bit the bullet and went last night, as they're part of Restaurant Week.  Of all of the menus available, this one spoke to us the most.
We arrived and were greeted and seated promptly.  We were surprised when we found out that a drink was included on top of our 3 course meal, and we both enjoyed  a glass of red wine.  They have a nice beer selection, with 5 or 6 Charlotte beers on tap (NoDa, Birdsong and Triple C) and 15-20 bottles.

On top of that, seasoned popcorn (nummers) and a deviled egg.  The deviled egg was okay, but it ain't grandma's! It tasted "right", just not up to the standards you would expect at a southern Sunday lunch.

For apps - Fried oysters on top of a slice of pineapple with a sliver of jalapeno. Good, not great.  Sweet Potato Soup with a chunk of chorizo.  Very rich and delicious. We would order again in a second!

For main course, I had the CAB Hangar steak with sweet potato/blue cheese gratin and my lady had the Pan-Seared Scallops with oven-roasted sweet potatoes, caramelized Brussels sprouts, red wine bloomed cranberries.

Both were incredibly tasty.  Both would be ordered again and I will recommend this place to any well to do attorney who wishes to treat a group of co-workers to a nice dinner!

We are on a bit of a Brussels Sprouts kick as of late, and these did not disappoint. Charred to perfection and seasoned well too.

To surmise, we'll be back and in the words of Biggie Smalls "If you don't know, now you know!"

So I finally made it here and left a little underwhelmed. 

I was not impressed with the parking situation. Seriously, even on a Tuesday night when you would think there would be plenty of open spaces....there just were not any. So you can valet or hope you don't get towed in the Rite Aid parking lot. Good luck with that! 

For me the menu was pretty limited. Now, I'm not saying they need 17 pages of choices but I would have liked something outside of chicken, fish and meatloaf. The side option selection was much better. 

I went with a burger, a side of mac and cheese and a cold glass of Triple C's Smoked Amber. Everything was just fine. Nothing really knocked my socks off and converted me into a fan but for what it was....A-Ok. 

What bothered me the most was that this place is SO loud. I couldn't hear anything. I seriously spent most of the night repeating things to my waitress and dining party which eventually turned into me yelling just to avoid repeating...No, thank you...I'll pass. 

I've been, checked it off my list but I won't be running back anytime soon.

I did not start off on the right foot with this restaurant. Their first contact with me was a phone call threatening to cancel my reservation if I did not call back to confirm "due to the increased business of restaurant week". I only had a party of 4 scheduled and looked on OpenTable to find there were still plenty of spots available leading up to my 6:30 reservation. It was for a Wednesday after all. This irked me so much I almost cancelled in favor of finding another restaurant for my group. 

By the time Wednesday rolled around 2 of the group were unable to attend so I easily updated the reservation. Part of me wishes I had not done that because our reserved table for 2 people was an uncomfortable high top at the bar. However people were generally helpful in retrieving my purse whenit kept falling off the chair with the rounded back. 

We started with a complimentary bowl of popcorn which had an interesting spicy BBQ seasoning on it. I ordered the tuna tartare as my appetizer which was delicious! I loved the sauces artfully spread across my plate to compliment the tuna. My sister said the fried oysters were delicious and I take her at her word since she left none for me to try!

I opted for the $5 upcharge to get the scallops. The plate contained 4 large and correctly cooked scallops but the seasoning on them was far too strong. I would have enjoyed the dish more if it had more of a scallop taste. 

The cheesecake at the end had a very coarse crust but the filling was good. 
The meal was delicious but the atmosphere and experience were lacking. I will probably return for drinks but not for dinner.
I love this place.  I have been here several times and have always had a great meal with great service.  I would certainly eat here again.

The atmosphere was cool, very cozy farmhouse style with reclaimed wood tables and Edison light bulbs. 

The waitstaff and management were very friendly, but not hovering. Although it was odd that all of the waitstaff were lined up in the dining room like they were waiting to pounce if your fork was laid down or your drink was a little empty!

 As for the food it was just ok. Not great not bad. I had the braised pork with Mac and Cheese which were both kind of bland. My husband had the  roasted chicken and veggies. All fresh! Simple but good.

The menu selections were simple but if done well could be good.

We have been anxiously awaiting the arrival of Nan & Bryon's in Dilworth. We live two blocks away and frequently walk to dine at Lucianos and 300 East. Our first disappointment is being served wine in juice tumblers. For heavens sake, who wants to drink red wine out of juice glass. (On a separate occasion, the GM told a friend of mine if he didn't like the wine glasses, he should order a vodka...I said 'WHAT'?).
Secondly, I am vegetarian, the choices are minimal but ok. I ordered the Portobello entree with two sides. My entree arrived on top of my sides. The flavor of all 3 things was now just ick. While I was away a week ago, my boyfriend revisited with friends and tried a shrimp entree. Still underwhelmed. Now they have rolled out lunch at the same prices as dinner. Personally, I'll give this place 2 more tries but it's unlikely that I'm going to drink wine out of a juice glass. Dilworth has a lot of nice restaurants who are anxious to please.
Got the Wagyu Flank and it was AMAZING!  A little noisy but we did have two large parties on either side of us.  Will definately be going back.

Have only been here for brunch. Price of an entree and 1 drink is about the same as the entire buffet which includes a bloody or mimosa (no brainier). That being said, if you go here you will eat too much. 

Typical American food brunch with some prime rib and (cold) shrimp and crab legs. Quality wise I wasn't overly impressed for a $22 brunch, probably won't bring here again, but nice to check it off the list. 

Most people make reservations so it will be really hard to go with a group without one. (Again, speaking about brunch.) The bar was open when I went so we just sat there without a reservation. 

Keep in mind, Sunday's in the South= no drinks before noon. I always forget that.

Love this place. Great food, drink and service. I highly recommend it. Nan's was able to quickly accommodate a large party for us even though we had no reservations and it was packed. Def try the new filet and chicken dish they just added to the menu!

We chose Nan and Byron's for our Mother's Day brunch, and couldn't have been more pleased. The setting was casual enough for our 4-year-old to not be a distraction, the service friendly, and the food outstanding.
